description: An ordinary paperback book.  Or is it?  It is.
While this seems like it would be very useful in this situation, the sheer amount of misinformation present makes it practically useless.
A full flight log for a military aircraft.  Nothing of interest stands out.
A little book for little readers.  The colorful cartoon characters and sweet stories contained herein belong to a different time, before the dead walked and the world moved on.
A short paper of the economic viability of constructing an agricultural outpost.
This binder details the scheduled maintenance for several plumbing systems throughout the facility.
A collection of essays by various authors from around the world, including works by Churchill, Mailer, Eco, and Voltaire.
An amusing collection of folklore featuring the usual cast of fairies, goblins, and trolls.
//: The ids below represent the Aarne-Thompson System of folklore classification.  Do not change.

snippet_category.text: This fairy tale is about a wolf who eats so much salted meat she becomes trapped in the butcher's cellar.
In this traditional story of beastly intrigue a clever fox convinces an elderly lion to kill a derogatory wolf.
This is an illustrated fairy tale book about a conversation between a mouse and a cat.
An amusing collection of stories featuring "Goldilocks and The Three Bears" on the cover.
This is a well illustrated fairy tale about a war between the birds and the beasts, with particulars on the wartime conduct and eventual fate of the bat.
This book, titled "The Rattlesnake's Vengeance" is a collection of Cherokee myths and legends.  "285D" is hand-written in pencil on the title page.
This fairy tale book is a regional variant of "Jack and the Beanstalk."
This fairy tale book is entitled "Little Red Cap".  It details a red-cloaked child's various encounters with talking wolves.
A collection of ghost stories warning about the dangers of stealing from the dead.
An Irish fairy tale in which a Celtic poet marries a princess who has been cursed with the head of a pig.
A book of Italian fairy tales translated into English.  The cover features an orange fairy juggling a lemon, a lime, and a tangerine.
A book of fables about people who change into birds.
This compendium of amusing folk tales about the devil is titled "Hell's Kettle: Legends of the Devil."
This charming book of Swedish fables is titled, "The Glass Mountain and the Princess."
This is a collection of fairy tale stories warning against the consequences of extreme greed.
This book is titled, "The Thieving Pot: Folktales of the Arab World."
This is a book of legends collected by Traveller Johnny Cassidy in the 1960s.
A book by the Brothers Grimm titled, "Eve's Unequal Children."
This book of fables expands upon the legend of the Seven Sleepers of Ephesus.
In this fairy tale a strong man frightens an ogre by squeezing water out of a stone.
This book of rustic folk tales bears the title: "How to Shout Down the Devil."
The title of this book is "Village Folk-tales of Ceylon."  It includes fables about logical errors and foolish misjudgements of the Kadambawa men.
This book of folk tales is titled, "The Girl with the Ugly Name, and Other Stories."
Titled "The Fleeing Pancake", this collection of silly folk tales is suitable for small children.

name.str: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Cataclysm
name.str_pl: copies of The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Cataclysm

description: Inscribed on the cover in large, friendly letters, is the message "Don't Panic".
A vellum book containing the hymns central to Marloss faith.  As the verses lead to each other, the text sings of unity and promised paradise.
An English translation of the Christian Bible, which originated in England in the early 1600s.
An English copy of the Eastern Orthodox translation of The Holy Bible.
An English translation of the Christian Bible, distributed free of charge by Gideons International.

name.str_pl: copies of The Guru Granth Sahib

description: A single-volume copy of the central religious texts of Sikhism.
A Muslim religious text containing an account of the sayings and actions of the prophet Muhammad.

A book that embodies the main beliefs of Discordianism.  It seems to primarily concern chaos, and features a card in the back which informs you that you are now a 'genuine and authorized Pope of Discordia'.
The oldest extant chronicle of Japan's myths and history, the stories contained in the Kojiki are part of the inspiration behind Shinto practices.

name.str_pl: copies of The Book of Mormon

description: The sacred text of the Latter Day Saint movement of Christianity, originally published in 1830 by Joseph Smith.

name.str: The Gospel of the Flying Spaghetti Monster
name.str_pl: copies of The Gospel of the Flying Spaghetti Monster

description: A book that embodies the main beliefs of the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster.  It seems to involve a lot of pirates and some sort of invisible drunken monster made of pasta.
An English translation of the Muslim book of holy scriptures, with explanatory notes and commentaries to aid in understanding.
This book is the canonical text of Scientology.  Written by a science fiction author, it contains self-improvement techniques and musings on psychology called Dianetics.

name.str_pl: copies of The Book of the SubGenius

description: A book about the Church of the SubGenius.  It seems to involve a salesman named J. R. "Bob" Dobbs and a concept called 'slack'.

name.str_pl: copies of The Sutras of the Buddha

description: A collection of discourses attributed to the Buddha and his close disciples.
One of the central texts of Rabbinic Judaism, the Talmud expounds upon the Hebrew Bible with teachings and opinions of thousands of rabbis.
A single-volume book containing the complete canon of the Jewish Bible.
A collection of sacred Buddhist writings describing their canons of scriptures.
A collection of sacred Hindu writings regarding the nature of reality and describing the character and form of human salvation.
A single volume containing all four Vedas, which are the oldest scriptures of Hinduism.
A collection of essays, observations, and rituals published by Anton LaVey in 1969.
A super-hero comic.
Reviews of recently released computer games and previews of upcoming titles.
Current events concerning a bunch of people who're all (un)dead now.
You can read it for the articles.  Or not.
A notepad with a number of frequencies scribbled on it.
A newsweekly covering regional events.  There is an article on the winter's snowstorms and several letters to the editor concerning the community response.
The stirring tale of a race against time, in search of a lost city located in the dark heart of the African continent.
A gripping tale of two friends struggling to survive on the streets of New York City.
A classic tale about growing up, portraying one young man's funny and poignant experiences with life, love, and sex.
A graphic novel about a young girl living in Iran during the 1980's, seeing the world change around her as Iraq invaded her country.
After their diamond heist goes wrong, the surviving criminals begin to suspect that one of them is a police informant.
A story about three people in the fictional city of Los Santos, a gangster, an upper-class man, and a psychopath, eventually banding together to pull-off the biggest heist in the city's history

name.str_pl: copies of Murdered by the Grapevine

description: This cheap paperback tells the story of a mob boss done in by mere suspicion.  She never breaks a confidence, never rats out an accomplice, and never turns her back on a friend.  Nonetheless her grip on the reigns of the underworld is eroded by rumor and paranoia.
A real book for real adults.
A hackneyed fictional narrative concealing low-grade literary smut.
A bizarre play about the philosophy of existential absurdity.  Or maybe it's about two guys waiting for their friend to show up.  It's confusing.
Basic sword & sorcery.
Maybe not the best reading material considering the situation.
A detective investigates an unusual murder in a secluded location.
A hardboiled detective tale filled with hard hitting action and intrigue.
A tale about a group of friends who wander the USA in the 1960s against a backdrop of jazz, poetry and drug use.
Drama and mild smut.
The classic tale of a wandering swordsman who comes to a small settlement and is hired to help the townsfolk defend themselves from a band of marauding outlaws.
A political satire of the pre-apocalypse world.  Looking back on it from this side of Armageddon makes it seem all the more ridiculous.
Aliens, ray guns, and space ships.

snippet_category.text: This is a copy of Gibson's "Neuromancer".  Written in the eighties, it was surprisingly accurate in predicting much of modern society…  Until recently.

This is a copy of "The Stars My Destination" by Alfred Bester.

Tyger, Tyger, Burning bright,
In the forests of the night:
What immortal hand or eye,
Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?
This is a copy of "The Lathe of Heaven" by Ursula Le Guin.  Dirty finger-stains have smudged the occasional word.
This is a copy of "The Dispossessed" by Ursula Le Guin.
This copy of Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451".
This is a copy of "Hyperion" by Dan Simmons.

This is a copy of "Endymion" by Dan Simmons.  It opens with a poem by D.H. Lawrence:

Give us gods.  Oh give them us!
Give us gods.
We are so tired of men
And motor-power.
This is a copy of Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?".
This is a dog-eared copy of "Nova Express" by William Burroughs.
This is a copy of "Foundation" by Isaac Asimov.  The back cover has been ripped off.
This is a dog-eared copy of "Dune" by Frank Herbert.  It has sand between some of its pages.  Weird.
This is a copy of "The Trial" by Franz Kafka.  This book is rather worn.
This is a copy of "The Handmaid's Tale" by Margaret Atwood.
This is a copy of "The Windup Girl" by Paolo Bacigalupi.  The blurb makes you wonder how Thailand fared the end of the world.
This is a copy of "Islands in the Net" by Bruce Sterling.
This is a copy of "Foundation and Empire" by Isaac Asimov.  The back page contains a hand-written grocery list.
This is an almost new copy of  "A Scanner Darkly" by Philip K. Dick.  It still has the smell of new books within it's pages.
This is a copy of "Mirrorshades: A Cyberpunk Anthology" compiled by Bruce Sterling.  The cover has rings of coffee stains over it.
This is a copy of "The World of Null-A" by A. E. van Vogt.  This copy looks to have been used to press flowers.
This is a copy of "Altered Carbon" by Richard Morgan.
This is a copy of Mary Shelly's "Frankenstein".  Wasn't that the name of the monster?
This is a copy of "Wasp" by Eric Frank Russel.  The futuristic terrorist's handbook.
This is a copy of "I Am Legend" by Richard Matheson.  The sleeve is covered in dried blood.
This is a copy of "Roadside Picnic" by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.
This is a copy of "The Forever War" by Joe Haldeman.  This copy looks as if it's been slightly chewed by a dog or other large animal.
This is a copy of "The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress" by Robert A. Heinlein.
This is a copy of "Cat's Cradle" by Kurt Vonnegut.  You notice there is a typo in the authors name on the spine of the book.
This is a copy of Samuel R. Delany's "Nova".  The cover reads "Review Copy.  Not for re-sale."
This is a copy of Vonnegut's "The Sirens of Titan".
This is a copy of "Grass" by Sheri S. Tepper.  A child has scribbled over the first pages in crayon.
This is a copy of William Gibson's "Count Zero".  The spine is stamped with 'Library Copy'.  And a sticker reading 'Science Fiction'.
This is a copy of "The Fifth Season" by N.K. Jemsin.  It smells faintly of dirt.
This is a copy of "The Weapon Makers" by A. E. van Vogt.
This is a copy of "Record of a Spaceborn Few" by Becky Chambers.  It looks almost brand new.
This is a copy of "Use of Weapons" by Ian M. Banks.  The spine is cracked and worn, some pages appear to be loose.
This is a copy of Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville's "Le Dernier Homme".
This is a copy of Orwell's "Nineteen Eighty-Four".  The pages are loose and thin.  You should probably be careful with this copy.
This is a copy of Heinlein's "Stranger in a Strange Land".  The cover is dog-eared and worn.
This is a copy of Orson Scott Card's "Ender's Game".
This is a weather worn copy of "Brave New World" by Aldous Huxley.
This is a copy of "The Lost World" by Arthur Conan Doyle.
This is a copy of "Islands in the Sky" by Arthur C. Clarke.
This is a copy of H. G. Wells' "The Island of Doctor Moreau".
This is a copy of Stanislaw Lem's "His Masters Voice".
This is a copy of Fred Hoyle's "The Black Cloud".
This is a copy of "Last and First Men" by Olaf Stapeldon.
This is a copy of Stanislaw Lem's "Solaris".
This is a copy of Theodore Sturgeon's "More Than Human".
This is a copy of "Vurt" by Jeff Noon.
This is a copy of "A Canticle for Leibowitz" by Walter M. Miller Jr.
This is a copy of "The War of The Worlds" by H.G Wells.
This is a copy of "Iron Sunrise" by Charles Stross.
This is a copy of "The Hunger Games" by Suzanne Collins.  Reading the blurb reminds you of a Japanese movie you think you once caught on the television late at night.
This is a copy of "The Day of the Triffids" by John Wyndham.
This is a copy of "A Clockwork Orange" by Anthony Burges.
This is a copy of "The Man Who Fell to Earth" by Walter Tevis.
This is a copy of "Simulacron-3" by Daniel F. Galouye.
This is a copy of "The Glass Bees" by Ernst Jünger.
This is a copy of "Journey to The Center of the Earth" by Jules Verne.
This is a copy of Larry Niven's "Ringworld".  There are a couple of pages missing from the end of the book.  Luckily only mail-order advertisements.
This is a well-worn copy of "The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy" by Douglas Adams.

description: The dramatic tale of a small-time boxer who gets a rare chance to fight the heavy-weight champion, and seize his one chance to make a better life for himself while impressing the cute girl who works in the pet store.
A tale of intrigue and espionage amongst Nazis, no, Commies, no, Iraqis!

name.str_pl: copies of Come Fly the Treacherous Skies

description: This tale of intrigue betrays the story of a debonair mechanic driven by a lust for revenge.  As she uncovers a sophisticated network of amateur pilots turned smugglers, the good guys and the bad guys begin to all look the same.

name.str: Lies, Damn Lies, and Rocket Science
name.str_pl: copies of Lies, Damn Lies, and Rocket Science

description: This spy novel tells the story of a jaded rocket scientist looking for redemption in all the wrong places.  As selling state secrets becomes her career, she learns there isn't much of difference between a double-agent and a triple-agent.
An exciting seventeenth century tale of how an enslaved Irish doctor and his comrades-in-chains escape and become heroic pirates of the Robin Hood variety.
A suspenseful tale of betrayal and revenge.
The story of two young lovers whose feuding families threaten to keep them apart.
A thrilling narrative of survival in a prisoner of war camp during the Second World War, filled with riveting subplots about rat farming and dysentery.
A story about a Bosnian citizen who goes through many hardships and near death during the breakup of Yugoslavia.
The classic tale of a gunfighting stranger who comes to a small settlement and is hired to help the townsfolk defend themselves from a band of marauding outlaws.
A deep discussion of morality with an emphasis on epistemology and logic.

snippet_category.text: This is a copy of Nietzsche's "Beyond Good and Evil".  Its cover is dog-eared and creased.
This is a copy of "The Unique and Its Property" by Max Stirner.  A modern translation by Wolfi Landstreicher.
This is a copy of Jean-Paul Sartre's "Being and Nothingness".  A key work in the existentialist tradition.
A large, extended version of "Madness and Civilisation" by Michel Foucault.  The cover features a striking image of a Panopticonic Prison.
This is a copy of "The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge" by Lyotard.
A collection of texts and essays by Jacques Derrida.  Its pages are loose and yellowed - you should probably handle it with care.
This is a copy of "Society of the Spectacle" by Guy Debord.  Its cover shows rows of adults staring placidly into a screen.
This is a split copy of both "An Ethic of Sexual Difference" and "This Sex Which Is Not One" by Luce Irigaray.

This is a copy of Baudrillard's "Simulation and Simulacra".  The cover contains an image of a man holding a colored pill in each hand, with the caption "Welcome to the Desert of the Real.".  You think you've seen this movie.
This is a small, pocket version of Sartre's "Existentialism and Humanism".  It looks to have been used as a coaster in a past life.
This is a copy of "Practical Ethics" by Peter Singer.  From the local university press.
This is a photocopied spiral-bound copy of "Industrial Society and Its Future" by 'Freedom Club'.  The original looks to have been written on a typewriter before being copied.
This is a copy of "Industrial Society and Its Future" by Ted Kaczynski.  Its cover is an image of a hand-crafted wooden box filled with wiring and an ominous looking metal tube.  Provocative.
This is a small reader on Hegel's Dialectics.
This is a copy of "The State and Revolution" by Vladimir Lenin.  In English, thankfully.
This is a copy of "In Defense of Marxism" by Leon Trotsky.
This is a copy of "Steal This Book" by Abbie Hoffman.  There is a security tag on the back cover.  It appears to still be active.
This is a copy of "Walden: Or Life In The Woods" by Henry David Thoreau.  It contains a dried and pressed leaf as a bookmark.
This is a copy of "The Female Eunuch" by Germaine Greer.  A child has scribbled over the contents page in red crayon.
This is a copy of "An Introduction to Metaphysics" by Bergson.
This is a copy of "The Four Fundamental Concepts of Psychoanalysis" by Jacques Lacan.
This is a copy of Machiavelli's "The Prince".  With intro by Q. Skinner.
This is a copy of "On The Revolution of Everyday Life" by Raul Vangeigem.
This is a pocket copy of "An Essay on Liberation" by Herbert Marcuse.  The cover contains an image of a pelican.
This is a copy of "Either-Or" by Søren Kierkegaard.
This is a copy of "Allegory of the Cave" by Plato.
This is a copy of "Leviathan" by Thomas Hobbes.
This is a copy of "Critique Of Pure Reason" by Immanuel Kant.
This is a copy of "Principles of Philosophy" by Descartes.
This is a copy of both "On The Genealogy of Morals" and "The Gay Science" by Friederich Nietzsche.
This is a copy of "The Myth of Sisyphus", and other essays, by Albert Camus.  The cover depicts a bare-chested man and a large boulder.
This is a copy of "The Sickness Unto Death" by Søren Kierkegaard.  The pages are dotted with post-it notes.
This is a copy of "The Defence of Terrorism" by Leon Trotsky.  Despite the title, it does not actually appear to be defending terrorism.
This is a copy of "Enquiry Concerning Political Justice" by William Godwin.  This thick book is filled with antiquated phrases.
This is a copy of "The Abolition of Work and Other Essays" by Bob Black.  It is likely that "The Abolition of Work" is the most famous essay in this book.
This is a copy of "What is Property?" by Pierre-Joseph Proudhon.  It looks like this book has a surprisingly long track record of owners.
This is a copy of "The Conquest of Bread" by Peter Kropotkin.  There is a picture of an old philosopher with magnificent beard, instead of bread, on the cover.
This is a copy of "The Trouble with Being Born" by Emil Cioran.  This book might have been printed decades before the Cataclysm since the cover is quite weathered.
This is a copy of "The World as Will and Representation" by Arthur Schopenhauer.  It contains a few undecipherable notes and scribbles.
This is a copy of "Up-Wingers: A Futurist Manifesto" by FM-2030.  It seems that the author's real name is Fereidoun M. Esfandiary.
This is a copy of "The Bastiat Collection", a large collection of essays by Frederic Bastiat.
This is a copy of "Anarchy, State, and Utopia" by Robert Nozick, one of the most influential books of modern libertarianism.
This is a copy of "Socialism" by Ludwig von Mises, a critical examination of socialism.
This is a copy of "The ABC of Communism" by Nikolai Bukharin, one of the most influential books of early Marxism-Leninism.
This is a copy of "Anti-Capitalist Mentality" by Ludwig von Mises.

description: This hefty volume contains the telephone numbers of individuals, businesses, and utilities in the nearby area, pretty useless during the apocalypse and all.
A leather album full of photos of somebody's family.  You don't know any of the people in them, but seeing these pictures still makes you think of happier times.
A collection of plays by various authors from around the world, including scripts by Wilde, Beckett, Checkov, and Shakespeare.
A collection of poetry by various authors from around the world, including writings by Dickinson, Goethe, Thoreau, and Yeats.
A small book filled with journal entries in Latin.
If you knew what to look for something might stand out…
A massive stack of medical records that contain every gory detail.
Old weather records are about as interesting as a rock.
This humongous volume contains a vast collection of short stories by different authors, spanning a wide variety of topics and genres.
An entertaining collection of early American folklore, featuring tales of larger than life individuals and their amazing adventures.
A small book detailing 'visions' a prisoner had on death row.
An English translation of several Old Norse poems.  The poems contain proverbs and stories attributed to the god Odin, many transcribed from oral history.
A book of classic literature, timeless and enjoyable but a bit dense to read.

snippet_category.text: This is a copy of Dickens' "Bleak House".
This is a copy of "Great Expectations" by Charles Dickens.
This is a copy of William Shinderling's "Under the Beech Trees".
This is a collection of three Jane Austen novels: "Pride and Prejudice", "Sense and Sensibility", and "Emma".
This is a well-worn paperback copy of "Lord of the Flies".
This is a copy of "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee.
This is a copy of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby."
This is copy of Michael Abanaderly's lesser-known work, "He Walks".
This is a collection of several vintage science fiction stories by Ray Bradbury.
This is a copy of "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" by Mark Twain.
This is an illustrated copy of "Innocents Abroad" by Mark Twain.
This is a copy of Bram Stoker's "Dracula", with scholarly commentary in the margins.
This is a large print copy of Tolstoy's "War and Peace".  It might make a decent improvised weapon.
This is a paperback copy of the well-known classic "Dark Days Ahead", by K. G. Ranade.  There are scrawled margin notes all over it, apparently the workings of a confused and feverish mind.
This is a copy of "Jane Eyre".  The cover art is quite out of place, making it look more like a dime-store romance novel.
This is a perfectly preserved hardcover copy of "The Gunslinger" by Stephen King, autographed by the author.  It contains a certificate of authenticity pronouncing it to be a first edition.
This paperback copy of "Wuthering Heights" has a large coffee stain on the first page.
This is a hardbound copy of "Lady Chatterly's Lover", by D. H. Lawrence.  It has some very explicit illustrations.
This is a hardbound copy of "The Catcher in the Rye.".  It has some very nicely done illustrations.
This is a collection of classic renaissance era stories, headlined by "Don Quixote".
This is a paperback copy of "The Fellowship of the Ring" by Tolkien.
This is a paperback copy of "The Two Towers" by Tolkien.
This is a paperback copy of "The Return of the King" by Tolkien.
This is a hardbound collection of George Orwell's works, including "1984" and "Animal Farm" as well as many of his less infamous titles.
This is a paperback copy of "Little Women" by Louisa May Alcott.  It appears to have been read a great many times.
This is a paperback copy of "Of Mice and Men" by Steinbeck.
This is a hefty hardcover copy of "Run and Run Again" by Finn Calpay.  There is a lengthy forward about the controversy around the book's release.
This is a hardcover copy of "The Gates Have Opened" by Arianna Methusalah.  You feel like you've read this before, but can't remember where.  Something about the book fills you with unease.
This is a copy of "The Count of Monte Cristo" by Dumas.
This is a copy of "The Secret Garden" by Frances Burnett.
This is a copy of "Lieutenant Hornblower" by C.S. Forester.
This is a copy of "Master and Commander" by Patrick O'Brian.
This is a copy of "The Warden" by Anthony Trollope.
This is a copy of "The Far Side of the World" by Patrick O'Brian.
This is a copy of "HMS Surprise" by Patrick O'Brian.
This is a copy of "Barchester Towers" by Anthony Trollope.
This is a copy of "The Land Ironclads" by H.G. Wells.
This is a copy of "The Great Boer War" by Arthur Conan Doyle.
This is a copy of "The Crime of the Congo" by Arthur Conan Doyle.
This is a copy of "The Parasite" by Arthur Conan Doyle.
This is a copy of "By Stroke of Sword" by Andrew Balfour.
This is a copy of "The Secret Agent" by Joseph Conrad.
This is a copy of "Lord Jim" by Joseph Conrad.
This is a copy of "Vanity Fair" by William Makepeace Thackeray.
This is a copy of "The Luck of Barry Lyndon" by William Makepeace Thackeray.
This is a copy of "North and South" by Elizabeth Gaskell.
This is a copy of "The Mayor of Casterbridge" by Thomas Hardy.
This is a copy of "Wessex Tales" by Thomas Hardy.
This is a copy of "Far from the Madding Crowd" by Thomas Hardy.
This is a copy of "Captains Courageous" by Rudyard Kipling.
This is a copy of "The Canterbury Tales" by Geoffrey Chaucer.
This is a copy of "Harold, the Last of the Saxons" by Edward Bulwer-Lytton.
This is a copy of "Mr Midshipman Easy" by Frederick Marryat.
This is a copy of "Peter Simple" by Frederick Marryat.

description: A unique, valuable book that has been kept as a collector's item.

snippet_category.text: This is a high-quality leather bound copy of Charles Dickens' "A Tale of Two Cities".
This is a very old but well-preserved copy of Charles Dickens' "Oliver Twist".
This high-quality copy of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is dog-eared and looks to have been read many times.
This is a hefty, hardcover print of William Shinderling's "Vanity before Justice" with beautiful illustrations.
This copy of Jane Austen's "Sense and Sensibility" has a certificate of authenticity declaring it to be an early edition.  It would have been worth an enormous amount of money, not long ago.
This is an excellent quality copy of "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee.
This is a high-quality leather bound copy of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby."
This is a hefty, hardcover print of Michael Abanaderly's opus, "Lady Wanderlust".  It is over a hundred years old, but doesn't look it.
This copy of Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451" has a certificate of authenticity declaring it to be an early edition.  It would have been worth an enormous amount of money, not long ago.
This high-quality copy of "Pride and Prejudice and Zombies" has been autographed by the author.

This is a high-quality leather bound copy of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" by Mark Twain.  It contains some margin notes which themselves are quite old, and look to have been done by a scholar of some sort.
This is a very nice print of Bram Stoker's "Dracula".  It has a certificate of authenticity with it that declares it a genuine early edition.
This copy of Douglas Adams' "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" has a certificate of authenticity declaring it to be a first edition, and is autographed by the author himself.
This is a high-quality leather bound copy of the well-known classic "Dark Days Ahead", by K. G. Ranade.
This is a well-kept leather bound copy of "Oryx and Crake" by Margaret Atwood.  Inscribed in the inner cover is a faded note wishing the owner a happy birthday.
This is a perfectly preserved hardcover copy of "The Gunslinger" by Stephen King, autographed by the author.  It contains a certificate of authenticity pronouncing it to be a first edition.
This bright orange hardcover copy of "1984" by George Orwell has been carefully preserved, and appears to be a first or second edition judging from the publisher's information.
This is a very nice copy of "Lady Chatterly's Lover", probably quite expensive in the days before the apocalypse.
This is a high quality early edition hardcover copy of "The Handmaid's Tale" by Margaret Atwood, signed by the author.

This ancient and worn book looks to be an 18th or early 19th century handwritten copy of "Don Quixote".  In the days of book traders it would have been worth an absolute fortune.  Now it's either a priceless piece of history, some light reading before bed, or excellent kindling.
This is a first edition copy of Terry Pratchett's "The Colour of Magic".  In the inner cover is a handwritten note that reads "To Chris, thanks for believing I could do it.  Best regards, Terry."
